availability.licence: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

correction.p: OCR generated transcript has not been corrected.

normalization.p: Only minor normalization where needed, if any, is indicated via markup.

punctuation.p: All punctuation marks in the source text have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.
Punctuation may be marked up with pc elements for clarification, but not exclusively.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.

hyphenation.p: Hyphenated words that appear at the end of a line have been retained. The hyphen, if present, is represented by the Unicode code point, and marked up with a pc element. The break="no" attribute on the lb element indicates that a single word is split across the lines.

interpretation.p: Dates, places, and names may be marked up, where useful.

body.ab:
RECIPES FOR COLORING
FAST COLORS,
ON WOOLEN AND COTTON.
Madder Red, on Woolen.
Tiilce 2 Iba MaMer.
4 oz. Mad'<ler (Jomponnd.
Let the madder soak twelve hours in siiiMcieiiL so^t water to coverthe cloth
you wish to dye, then add tlie madder compound, wet your cloth in clean soft
water, v.rin}? it out and put it into the dye, place the kettle over the tire and
bring it slowly to a scalding heat; keep it at this heat for one-half hour if alight
red is wanted, and longer if you desire a dar^ one, or until you have the desired
rinse immediai.ely in cold soft water. (Kemember that fretiuently
raismgHre cloth with a clean stick so aS to expose it^to the air wTll very Inuch
improve the color.)
For 4 lbs. Beantifvd Scarlet, on Woolen.
Take 4 oz. Powdered. Cochineal.
4 oz. Pure Cream, Tartar.
I 8 Cochineal (h»npoiind.
8 oz. Ahrm.
Bring to a boiling heat sufficient .soft water to cover the-cloth j-ou intend to
(lye, then add the pow(iered cochineal, and pure cream tartar, boil for ten min
utes, then add the cochineal compound, stir them well together with a clean
stick, then strain, after which the cloth or yarn may be put in and kept hot for
half an hour, frequently stirring and e.Kposing to the air, then remove from the
dye and rinse in alum water made by dissolving 4 oz. alum in one gallon of soft
water.
For 4 lbs. Pink, on Woolen.
Take 1 oz. Powdered CoeJUneal.
Boil 'he powdered coch neal in sufficient soft water to cover your cloth, for
half an hour, then strain carefully to i-emove all sediment, and put in youf
cloth iia\Jng been.previously soaked in alum ,wa^er,jan(n*?t stand lyjtil you
liave the*lesir^d shacte
For 4 lbs. Royal Purple, on Woolen.
Take. 14 oz. (tudbe ir.
Boll the cudbear in sufficient soft water to cover \ our cltxtli, foi* half an
lionr. then strain until you have removed all the sediment, and bMngagain tea
boiling hea : then soak your cloth in strong saleratus water, and put it into
ihe dye and let it remain until you have the desired shade.
For 4 lbs. Orange, on AVoolen or Cotton.
Take (> oz. 8uga,r Lead.
4 irz. Bkhroruate Pota.di.
Bring to a boiling heat in two kettles sufficient soft watei- iw^each to cover
your cloth: then add to one kettle t'le sugar lea^^ and to the other the bichro
mate of potash: then soak youi- cloth in lime water (of the proper sti-ength to
drink.) then place your cloth in the kettle of lead, and boil five niinutes. then
tj-ansfer it to, the kettle of bichromate potash and simmer until you h ve the
tiesired shavlp, then rinse as usual.
4
For 4 lbs. Yellow, on "Woolen or Cotton.
Tnlcf. 4 oz. Svrjar Lend.
3 (». Bichromate Potn.ih.
Proceed in the same manner as for Orange.
For 4 lbs. Yellow on "NToolen.
Take 8 the. FmPk.
1,V ite. Alum.
Steep to get the strength and proceed as usual.
Note.—Saffron, steeped in earthen and strained, colors a fine straw color.
It makes a delicate or deep shade according to the strength of it.
For 4 lbs. Blue on Woolen.
Take oz. Alum. . -—
5 oz. Crenm Tartar.
4 oz. Gliemic Blue.
Bring to a boiling heat in a brass kettle, suffloient soft water to cover your
cloth, then add the alum and the cream tartar, when dissolved put in your
cloth and boil one hour; it is then to be taken out and thrown into warm
water, previously mixed with a greater or less prnportion of chemic blue,
according to the shade tiie cloth is intended to i-eceive. In this water it must
be boiled until it has ac(iuired the desired coioi-.
For 4 lbs. Bine, on Cotton.
Take ti oz. Copper/u.
0 oz. Frvsieiate Pota!,h. '
. 2 oz^. Sulphuric Arid. |, '
Dissolve the copperas and the prussiate potash in sufllcient hot water to
cover your cloth; put in your ciotii and let it remain for half an hour, frequent
ly raising ir to the air, tiien take out your cloth and add your sulphuric acid,
stir ail well together,then put in your cloth again and keep liot until your cloth
is colored. Color in brass.
For 4 lbs. Green on Cotton.
Take 3 oz. Coppernst. i/'' ̂
4 oz. Pniiidate Pata.rh.
3 oz. Bichromate Pota/h. ̂
,Su(/ar Lend. /
Salphuric Acid. ̂
3 oz.
Dissolve the capperas, prussiate of potash, bichromate potash, and the
sugar iLd in sufficient hot water to cover your cloth; put in your cloth and
let it remain halt an hour, then take out yr iir cloth and add the suiphnnc acid;
stir well together and again put in your ciotii, only keep hot until colored.
Color in brass.
For 4 11)S. Gi'een, on Woolen,
Take 1 Ih. Alam.
4 Wi.t. Fu.rt.ic.
4 eiz. Chemic Blue.
Steep the fustic (not boil) until the strengtii is out, add the alum and soak
the cloth in it uiiTii it acquires a good yellow, then remove the chips and add
tiie chemic blue br degrees, niitii you have the desired color.
